Ruthenium (Ru)-based materials are considered significantly promising alternative electrocatalysts, benefiting from the fact that it has similar hydrogen bonding energy to Pt and is much cheaper than Pt toward the industrial alkaline hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, the weak kinetics of water dissociation for water is reduced to hydrogen by electrochemistry in alkaline solutions impedes seriously its practical application. We propose a novel and efficient method for preparing Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA hybrids, inspired by the reducibility and excellent adhesion of Polydopamine (PDA). It is interesting that in the process of preparing Ru nanoparticles by electrodeposition, the reduction rate of Ru can be adjusted by the PDA attached to the surface of nickel foam so that Ru/RuO2 hybrids with crystal structure can be prepared. Meanwhile, the amorphous Ni(OH)2 nanoarray was grown on the surface of PDA without additional Ni source. The experimental and simulation consequence showed that the mussel-inspired polydopamine transition layer significantly improves the activity of Ru/RuO2 nanoparticles for HER, which is due to the change in electronic structure caused by the favorable interaction between amorphous Ni(OH)2 and crystalline Ru-RuO2. Astonishingly, the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA electrode presented an overpotential of merely 154 mV at a current density of 1000 mA cm⁻² in an alkaline medium. (1 M KOH), and simultaneously demonstrating prominent long-term stability for 600 h. This work supplies a neoteric venue for optimizing ruthenium-based electrocatalysts toward industrial green hydrogen production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Inspired by the reducibility and good adhesion of Polydopamine (PDA), we propose a new and efficient method for preparing Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA hybrids. The prepared Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA electrode displayed overpotential of only 154 mV at high current density of 1000 mA cm-2 in alkaline solution (1 M KOH), and simultaneously demonstrating prominent long-term stability for 600 h. Keywords Ruthenium-based catalyst Electrocatalysis Alkaline electrolyzed water High current density Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Hydrogen energy, as a green, safe, efficient, high-energy density, and environmentally low-impact characteristics secondary energy source has deemed to be a potential alternative power carrier to traditional fossil energy, which can promote the plant-scale application of renewable energy [1–3]. Of all the hydrogen production techniques, alkaline water electrolysis (AWE) is viewed as the best promising and broadly accepted for industrialization [4,5]. However, water electrolysis technology is still distant from satisfactory for industrial applications (1000 mA cm-2) due to the shortage of economically competitive, high efficient and steady-going compounds involved in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [6–9]. To realize industrial hydrogen evolution, It is essential to design a more efficient electrocatalyst with ampere level current densities and durable operating stability for HER [10–12]. Although, platinum (Pt) is still be seen as the benchmark electrocatalyst for HER in commercial application at present on account to the optimal hydrogen adsorption free energy [13–16]. The high cost, scarcity and poor stability at high current densities of Pt stymie its large-scale applications [17–19]. Ruthenium (Ru), belonging to the Pt-group of metals, based materials are a promising alternative to Pt by reason of the suitable metal-hydrogen bond intensity (65 kcal mol-1) and comparatively low cost (only one-third that of Pt) [20–23]. However, the weak ability of water dissociation and irreversible agglomeration contribute to inadequate HER activity and stability when current densities are high with extreme conditions [24–28]. Thus, it is highly desired to rational design Ru-based electrocatalysts to simultaneously optimize water dissociation kinetics and enhance catalytic stability towards the HER performance for the industrial hydrogen production. Recently, considerable efforts have demonstrated that nickel hydroxide (Ni(OH)2) nanosheets can efficaciously cracking the H–OH bond for dissociating water molecules. However, the reaction performance of Ni(OH)2 nanosheets is not satisfactory for HER activity by reason of the poor conductivity. As a consequence, s integrating strategies are usually adopted to design a high-efficient electrocatalyst with the synergistic effect for HER. Yu and co-workers reported that Ru in its atomic form was secured on Ni(OH)2 nanoribbon obviously reduce the kinetic energy barrier and subsequently promoting the HER performance [29]. Nevertheless, the evaluation of numerous HER electrocatalysts was conducted at low current densities of 10 mA cm-2, which is not suitable for practical purposes. Zhu and co-workers composited Ni(OH)2 layers embedded Ru quantum dots (QDs) with a simple hydrothermal procedure. With an overpotential of 105.1 mV at 300 mA cm- 2, the catalysts exhibited strong HER catalytic ability [30]. Ren and co-workers prepared Fe adulterated Ru/Ni(OH)2 (Ru/(Fe,Ni)(OH)2) nanosheet arrays by hydrothermal and self-reduction method. The obtained Ru/(Fe,Ni)(OH)2 just needed an overpotential of 152 mV to actuate 1000 mA cm- 2 for HER [31]. The above results showed that the HER activity can be boosted by regulating the structure or electronic structure of Ru, but the stability at high current density needs to be further improved. This further demonstrates that coupling highly active noble metals with transition metals through doping or similar approaches is a highly effective strategy for fabricating efficient electrocatalysts, which not only reduces costs but also enhances catalytic performance [32,33]. Cao et al. proved that Ru-based catalysts stability could be improved by coating with polyaniline (PANI) by reducing dissolution in harsh electrolytes environment [34]. Polydopamine (PDA), a material inspired by mussels, has a unique property of forming interfacial coatings and supporting the anchoring of metal ions and particles. Wang et al. have verified that Polydopamine (PDA) as a bio-inspired coating material can inhibit Ru-Ni(OH)2 erosion during HER reaction, thereby improving the catalyst stability, which has generated considerable attention during the past few years [35]. Furthermore, the construction of the special structures combining the crystal and amorphous phases have been demonstrated to accelerate the HER process. Inspired by these works, we propose a new strategy for preparing Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF composite catalysts based on PDA-regulated crystalline Ru-RuO2 and amorphous Ni(OH)2 nanosheet arrays via a facile self-polymerization reaction of dopamine on Ni foam (NF) followed by electrodeposition method. In particular, PDA not only can be coated on the NF uniformly with the strong adhesion but also control the reduction rate of Ru to form crystalline Ru-RuO2 in the process of electrodeposition. The presence of PDA induced partial hydrolysis of Ru3+ to RuO2. Meanwhile, due to the weak acidity of PDA solution, Ni2+ ions were formed by etching foam nickel in the process of polymerization to form PDA, and the formed Ni2+ ions were introduced into the PDA. During the electrodeposition of Ru, Ni2+ ions were converted to amorphous Ni(OH)2, forming a Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF composite catalyst as depicted in Fig 1 a. The obtained crystalline/amorphous heterostructure catalyst showed exceptional HER performance with remarkably low overpotentials of 112 and 154 mV at the present densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm-2, separately, in alkaline solution (1 M KOH). Simultaneously, the Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF catalyst is subjected to a high current density of 1000 mA cm-2, it displayed the extraordinary long-term stability for over 600 h, suggesting its suitability for practical application. The pronounced interaction within the crystalline Ru-RuO2 and amorphous Ni(OH)2 that regulated the electronic structure, which modulates the HER activity. Density function theory calculation was consistent with the experimental result. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Synthesis of PDA/NF The pre-treated nickel foam was placed in (9 mg mL-1) dopamine hydrochloride solution for 12 h, and put into a vacuum oven to dry for 6 h to acquire the PDA/NF electrode deposited with polydopamine. 2.2 Synthesis of Ru-RuO2-Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF The PDA/NF electrode served as the working electrode, while a Hg/HgO electrode was used as the reference and a platinum sheet acted as the counter electrode. Electrodeposition was carried out in a three-electrode setup using 0.02 M RuCl3·3H2O as the electrolyte solution. The deposition was carried out at a constant voltage of −1 V for 1 h, resulting in the formation of the PDA-Ru/NF electrode, also referred to as the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2 electrode. For details on the preparation of the remaining comparison catalysts and the commercial Pt/C electrode, please refer to the supplementary materials. 2.3 Material characterizations The synthesized electrode catalyst materials were systematically characterized through a series of advanced analytical techniques. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Bruker, Cu Kα radiation, 10–90°) was conducted to elucidate the crystalline phase and structural properties of the materials. The surface morphology and microstructural attributes were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Sigma 300) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30), providing detailed insights into the materials’ surface topography and morphological characteristics. Raman spectroscopy (LabRam HR Evolution) was employed to probe the molecular structure and bond configurations within the samples, while X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Escalab 250XI) offered an in-depth analysis of the elemental composition and electronic states, revealing the chemical environment and oxidation states present. Additionally, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Agilent 7800) enabled precise quantification of the elemental concentrations, including trace elements, within the material matrix, enhancing the comprehensive understanding of its elemental profile. 2.4 Electrochemical tests All the catalysts prepared above were tested by electrochemistry, including LSV, CV and EIS. After that, the electrochemical performance parameters such as Tafel slope, Cdl and ECSA of various materials were obtained by calculating the data. At the same time, the stability of catalyst and Faraday efficiency of whole water cracking were tested. See the electrochemical test of supporting materials for specific experimental parameter conditions and parameter settings. 2.5 DFT All spin-polarized DFT calculations were executed with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), using the VASP, implemented through the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [36–38]. The energy cut-off was set at 520 eV and 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh was applied. Projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials were utilized to approximate valence electron densities and core-valence interactions [39]. Additionally, the Grimme method for DFT-D3 dispersion corrections was employed [40]. The force and energy convergence criteria were set lower than 0.03 eV∙Å-1 and 1 × 10–5 eV, respectively. Ni(OH)2 (100), Ru (100), RuO2 (110), Ni(OH)2/Ru, Ni(OH)2/Ru/RuO2, RuO2/Ru were modeled with the bottom one layer fixed and the upper layers relaxed. To ensure accurate calculations, a vacuum layer of 20 Å was added along the z-axis [41,42]. Subsequently, free energy corrections were performed using vaspkit [38,43] with the temperature set to 298.15 K. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural characterization As depicted in Fig. 1a, Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF electrode was prepared by the following two steps. Firstly, the smooth PDA films were deposited uniformly on the surface of NF by self-polymerization of the dopamine (Fig. 1b and Fig. S1). Then, the Ru electrodeposition process was performed in a three-electrode system with RuCl3 electrolyte at ambient temperature. Interestingly, after electrodeposition, the surface of nickel foam (NF) grew compact nano-arrays (Fig. 1c and 1d), indicating that the development of Ni(OH)2, possibly due to the attachment of Ni2+ to the PDA surface. In order to verify the presence of Ni2+, ICP test was performed on PDA solution after NF immersed in PDA solution for 12 h. The results indicated that the concentration of Ni2+ in PDA solution was about 475 mg mL-1, which indicated that nickel foam can also be etched into nickel ions and adsorbed on PDA. Therefore, nickel ions on the surface of PDA were converted into Ni(OH)2 nanoarrays during the electrodeposition process. To investigate further details in the morphology and microstructure, TEM characterization was analyzed. Fig. 1e displayed the Ni(OH)2 nanoarrays with curl and wrinkle were observed clearly, which was consistent with the above SEM results (Fig. 1d). The layered or nanosheet structure provides a high specific surface area and abundant exposed edge active sites, facilitating the adsorption/desorption of reactive intermediates (H*) [44,45], while the hydrophilic Ni(OH)2 surface enhances electrolyte permeation, reduces bubble adhesion, and accelerates reaction kinetics [46]. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image revealed distinct crystal lattice stripes with pitches measuring 0.202 nm and 0.220 nm, as illustrated in Fig 1f. These measurements align with the (101) crystal plane of ruthenium (Ru) and the (220) crystal plane of ruthenium dioxide (RuO2) [47], respectively. This observation highlights the structural characteristics of the materials under investigation, providing insight into their crystallographic features. Additionally, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern showcased in Fig 1 g displayed two crystalline structures that correspond to the (101) plane of Ru and the (110) and (220) planes of RuO2. This observation signifies the formation of a composite structure consisting of both Ru and RuO2, thereby confirming the interaction and potential synergy between these two materials in their crystalline forms. Moreover, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping, as pictured in Fig 1h, confirmed the even distribution of elements within the nanosheets. Specifically, nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), nickel (Ni), and ruthenium (Ru) were found to be homogeneously spread across the surface of the nanosheets. This finding not only affirms the successful synthesis of the composite material but also suggests its uniformity, which is crucial for ensuring consistent material properties in potential applications. However, the interplanar spacing of Ni(OH)2 based on the HRTEM and the corresponding diffraction fringe were not observed, demonstrating that the Ni(OH)2 exhibited an amorphous feature. Therefore, it could be speculated that PDA promoted the formation of crystalline Ru-RuO2 species and the formation of amorphous Ni(OH)2 nanosheets during electrodeposition. All the above described results confirmed that the PDA-regulated Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2 electrode showed crystalline-amorphous structure, which may promote the HER process. To study the phase and structure of the composites further, XRD was employed to characterize the prepared materials. As can be seen from Fig. 2 a, only the characteristic peaks of Ni (PDF#04–0850) were observed, which indicated that Ni(OH)2 was mainly presented in the form of an amorphous phase, being well matched with the TEM results [48]. In the bargain, the diffraction peaks of metallic Ru-RuO2 were also not detected, which further indicated that the loading of Ru species was low (analyzed by ICP, 5.5 mg cm-2) and evenly distributed [49]. Furthermore, the detailed construction of the prepared catalysts was further analyzed by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 2b, there were two strong characteristic peaks at 1321 and 1581 cm-1 for both PDA/NF and Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF, which corresponded to the aromatic ring stretching and deformation modes of PDA, respectively, indicating the presence of PDA [50]. Additionally, the characteristic peak at about 680 cm-1 corresponding to the Eg peak of RuO2 was detected, which certified the existence of RuO2 phase on the superficial of the compound [51]. Compared with PDA/NF, the profile of Ru-RuO2 Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF showed a characteristic peak at 489 cm-1, which belonged to Ni-O of Ni(OH)2 [52–54]. The above results demonstrated that the formation of Ru species and Ni(OH)2 on the surface of PDA/NF by electrodeposition. The technology of XPS was utilized to examine the chemical components and oxidation states of the synthesized materials. The full XPS spectra revealed the exist of C, N, O, Ni and Ru elements on the surface of prepared electrode (Fig. S2a). Additionally, it was revealed that the ratios of Ni and O increased after electrodeposition (Fig. S2b), which further indicated the formation of Ni(OH)2. The high-resolution spectra of N, Ni, O and Ru were analyzed. Fig. 3 a showed the XPS N 1 s spectrum of PDA/NF could be matched into three peaks at 398.7, 399.8 and 401.5 eV attributing to the binding energy of =N-, -NH- and -NH2, respectively [50]. After electrodeposition, the peak of -NH2 shifted from 401.5 eV to 400.6 eV, whereas the others remain unchanged, implying the possible strong reaction in ammonium group sites and Ru. Following this, the O 1 s spectrum of PDA/NF was analyzed using deconvolution techniques, which revealed two distinct peaks. These peaks were identified at binding energies of 532.9 eV and 531.3 eV, respectively. The peak at 532.9 eV is related with the carbonyl (C = O) functional group, while the peak at 531.3 eV corresponds to the CO functional group. This analysis is illustrated in Fig. 3b [55]. Remarkably, a new peak located at 530.4 eV was appeared, which was distributed to Ru-O, indicating that the formation of RuO2 [56]. Fig. 3c presented the high-resolution spectrum for Ru 3p Two main peaks were observed at 461.7 eV and 483.6 eV, corresponding to the Ru 3p3/2 and Ru 3p1/2 signals of ruthenium in its metallic form. Furthermore, the Ru 3p peaks at 464.2 eV and 486.2 eV can be identified as signals from RuO2 [57]. The above results expressed that the part of Ru0 was oxidized to RuO2 due to the presence of PDA. In addition, the analysis of the Ni 2p region in the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF sample revealed significant peaks that correspond to the electronic states of nickel. Specifically, the peaks observed at binding energies of 856 eV and 873.4 eV can be attributed to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 levels of nickel hydroxide (Ni(OH)2), respectively [58]. The above results further manifested the formation of Ni(OH)2 during electrodeposition. Compared to metallic nickel, high-valent nickel species facilitate water adsorption and dissociation, thereby lowering the HER reaction energy barrier and enhancing catalytic activity [59,60]. 3.2 Electrocatalytic properties for HER The electrocatalytic performance of the HER catalyst was studied in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte using a standard three-electrode system. The linear sweep voltammetry curve is shown in Fig. 4 a. Particularly, the ideal Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF electrode exhibits enhanced HER reactivity at high current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm-2 and low overpotentials of 112 and 154 mV. which surpassed the mercantile Pt/C (256 mV@500 mA cm-2, 405 mV@1000 mA cm-2), PDA/NF (487 mV@500 mA cm-2, 576 mV@1000 mA cm-2), Ru/NF (174 mV@500 mA cm-2, 275 mV@1000 mA cm-2) and those previously reported (Table S1). The Ru-RuO2/NF reference catalyst was also synthesized and subjected to electrochemical testing. Although its HER performance (166 mV @ 500 mA cm-2, 269 mV @ 1000 mA cm-2) surpassed that of commercial Pt/C, it still underperformed relative to the ultimate catalyst (Fig. S6 a). Furthermore, the preparation conditions of Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF were optimized involving the deposition time and concentration of PDA (Fig. S3), electrodeposition voltage, electrodeposition time and electrolyte concentration (Fig. S4). Additionally, the corresponding Tafel slope of the catalysts was employed to assess reaction kinetics during the HER course. As shown in Fig. 4b and Fig S6 b, what we have prepared the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF electrode displayed a quite small Tafel slope of 67.3 mV dec‑1, which was significantly under those of NF (136.7 mV dec‑1), PDA/NF (135.3 mV dec‑1), Pt/C (79.8 mV dec‑1), Ru-RuO2/NF (80.17 mV dec‑1) and Ru/NF (75.4 mV dec‑1), indicating that the prepared Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF catalyst exhibited rapid reaction kinetics. At the same time, The Tafel slope values of the electrodes ranged from 40 to 120 mV dec‑1, indicating that the Volmer-Heyrovsky process is the rate-limiting step of the HER process. For the sake of further analyze the chemical kinetics information of electrodes, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was executed. As depicted in Fig. 4c, the Nyquist plot of Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF displayed a smaller radius compared to other catalysts. The corresponding charge transfer resistance (Rct) acquired by the fitting of the EIS data was 0.15 Ω (Fig. 4c), which was markedly lower than that of NF (83.60 Ω), PDA/NF (83.40 Ω), Ru/NF (0.90 Ω) and commercial Pt/C (2.70 Ω). This shows that among the materials listed above, the best prepared catalysts have the lowest charge transfer resistance, highlighting its superior efficiency in the HER reaction. In addition, the ESCA of Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF was further evaluated, which was related to the Cdl of the prepared materials. As shown in Fig. 4d, the Cdl value of Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF was computed according to different cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. S5 e). The Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF exhibited the supreme Cdl performance (80.6 mF cm-2) than that of NF (1.73 mF cm-2), PDA/NF (2.77 mF cm-2), Ru/NF (41.3 mF cm-2) and Pt/C (33.4 mF cm-2), signifying much more accessible reactive sites for Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF, which was beneficial to promote the intrinsic catalytic capacity for HER process. Based on the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) derived from cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements, the calculated ECSA and RF values reached 2015 cm-2 and 8060, respectively [61]. Moreover, for the sake of evaluate the durability of the prepared materials, the chronopotentiometry test was implementing at ampere-level current density of 1000 mA cm-2 (Fig. 4e). Impressively, the optimal electrode showed negligible decline after 600 h, manifesting the remarkable stability at high current density. In addition, the Faradaic efficiency (FE) of the electrode was evaluated to determine its charge utilization efficiency. As shown in Fig. S5 f, the volumes of oxygen and hydrogen were obtained by using a Hoffmann electrolysis apparatus, where the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF electrode serving as the negative electrode and commercial RuO2 as the positive. The volume ratio of H2 to O2 approximated 2:1 and the calculated Faradaic efficiency for Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF||RuO2 system was about 95.5 %, reflecting high efficiency in charge utilization. The above results showed Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF was a potential catalyst for industrial application. 3.3 Mechanism analysis by DFT To further investigate the influence of the structural characteristics of crystalline/amorphous heterostructure catalysts on their performance, DFT calculations were conducted. These analyses primarily included the charge density difference analysis for Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2 and Ru/Ni(OH)2 structures, the density of states (DOS), and the adsorption energy of hydrogen intermediates (H*). As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, the charge density difference analysis revealed significant charge transfer from the Ru/RuO2 structure to the adjacent Ni(OH)2 layer in the heterostructure. The magnitude of charge transfer was quantified as 0.609 e, which exceeds the charge transfer observed in the Ru/Ni(OH)2 structure (0.517 e). This charge transfer effectively modulates the d-band center of Ru. As shown in Fig. 5b, the d-band center of Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2 (−2.299 eV) exhibits a more pronounced downshift compared to Ru-RuO2 (−1.793 eV) and Ru/Ni(OH)2 (−2.223 eV). The downshift of the d-band center triggers electronic charge redistribution within Ru atoms, optimizing hydrogen intermediate (H*) adsorption at catalytic active sites. This downshift facilitates a reduction in H* adsorption energy, thereby promoting the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [60,62]. Furthermore, the ΔG H* values for various catalytic structures were calculated (Fig. 5c). The inset illustrates the hydrogen adsorption configurations for each catalyst (from left to right: Ni(OH)2, Ni(OH)2/Ru, RuO2/Ru, Ru, RuO2, and Ni(OH)2/Ru/RuO2). Among them, Ni(OH)2 (0.57 eV) and RuO2 (−1.25 eV) exhibited the highest and lowest ΔG H* values, respectively. Notably, the crystalline/amorphous heterostructure Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2 (−0.37 eV) demonstrated the most favorable ΔG H* value. These computational results displayed that the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF catalyst exhibits enhanced catalytic activity and stability due to the formation of the crystalline/amorphous heterostructure Ru-RuO2. This structural feature effectively modulates the d-band center of the catalytic active sites, optimizing the adsorption energy of H* during the HER process and consequently improving the overall catalytic performance. 4 Conclusion In summary, PDA as the transition layer with good adhesion, adsorption and oxidation–reduction properties can regulate the ratio of Ru and RuO2 in the process of preparing Ru by electrodeposition, and provide Ni2+ attachment point for the constitution of Ni(OH)2, and ultimately prepared amorphous Ni(OH)2 and crystalline Ru-RuO2 (Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF). The outcome showed that the optimized Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF catalyst achieved current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm-2 at overpotentials of only 112 mV and 154 mV, individually. Moreover, the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA/NF catalyst displayed remarkable stability after chronoamperometric tests, showing no significant current degradation after over 600 h. This research provides a innovative technique for the fabrication of ruthenium-based catalysts for industrial hydrogen production. coredata.dc:description: Ruthenium (Ru)-based materials are considered significantly promising alternative electrocatalysts, benefiting from the fact that it has similar hydrogen bonding energy to Pt and is much cheaper than Pt toward the industrial alkaline hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, the weak kinetics of water dissociation for water is reduced to hydrogen by electrochemistry in alkaline solutions impedes seriously its practical application. We propose a novel and efficient method for preparing Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA hybrids, inspired by the reducibility and excellent adhesion of Polydopamine (PDA). It is interesting that in the process of preparing Ru nanoparticles by electrodeposition, the reduction rate of Ru can be adjusted by the PDA attached to the surface of nickel foam so that Ru/RuO2 hybrids with crystal structure can be prepared. Meanwhile, the amorphous Ni(OH)2 nanoarray was grown on the surface of PDA without additional Ni source. The experimental and simulation consequence showed that the mussel-inspired polydopamine transition layer significantly improves the activity of Ru/RuO2 nanoparticles for HER, which is due to the change in electronic structure caused by the favorable interaction between amorphous Ni(OH)2 and crystalline Ru-RuO2. Astonishingly, the Ru-RuO2/Ni(OH)2/PDA electrode presented an overpotential of merely 154 mV at a current density of 1000 mA cm⁻² in an alkaline medium. (1 M KOH), and simultaneously demonstrating prominent long-term stability for 600 h. This work supplies a neoteric venue for optimizing ruthenium-based electrocatalysts toward industrial green hydrogen production.
